newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-JACQUET WARNS PLAYERS TO THINK OF FRANCE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-JACQUET WARNS PLAYERS TO THINK OF FRANCE.

text.p: French soccer manager Aime Jacquet has warned his players not to ignore their international obligations as they seek to further their club careers.
Since the Bosman ruling, which allowed players to move freely between clubs, France has lost many of its best soccer talents to wealthy Italian, Spanish and English clubs.
And with France qualified automatically as host of the 1998 World Cup and playing only friendlies, Jacquet is concerned that players' dedication to the national cause might be taking a back seat.

"I handed players a little memo asking them to be very careful about the clubs they would be signing for next season," said Jacquet at a gathering 40 potential World Cup players near Paris for the Easter weekend.
The manager is worried about players signing lucrative deals with big-name clubs but then not being able to secure a first team place.
"I warned them they should join clubs where they will be playing regularly. I also asked them to take real holidays," he added.
"I told them it was the season they should not miss. Consistency on the pitch will be for me a decisive factor," he said.
"For me, the World Cup has already started. It is an exceptional period and I want players to be exceptional".
Players underwent medical checks during the weekend and Jacquet said they had shown that many were suffering from muscular and tendon problems.
